At our Friday April 25th meeting at the Archive, we decided that
in the interest of having a demoable and focused-usable crawler
as soon as possible, we would be adopting a synchronous, multiple-
threaded design in the Mercator style, rather than continuing
the investigation of other more novel architectures. 

(The meetings with the National Libraries last week only further
suggest that an early usable focused crawler will be valuable.)

This wasn't summarized out to the team given intervening events
and travels, but some of its implications for current work include:

- investigation of staged/asynch performance and designs should
  be put on indefinite hold
- design work now assumes a concrete approach involving worker 
  threads
- fetching (HTTP and DNS) work can change to assume synchronous
  blocking is OK

The central idea that a CrawlURI instance is passed to a series
of modules ("Processors") which include preprocessors, fetchers,
analyzes, etc. remains the same. Asynchronous queues will likely 
still feature prominently as URIs move from the Scheduler to 
workers, and then back from workers to the URIDB.

- Gordon
